title: Desirability Functions for Multiparameter Optimization
text: Suppose classification model two tuning parameters (penalty mixture) several performance measures (multinomial log-loss, area precision-recall curve, area ROC curve). tuning parameter, average number features used model also computed: might want pick model way maximizes area ROC curve minimum number model terms. know ROC measures usually 0.5 1.0. can define desirability function maximize value using: number terms, wanted minimize condition less 100 features, minimal desirability function can appropriate: can add columns data using mutate() statement along call function blends values using geometric mean: See ?inline_desirability details individual desirability functions.

title: Desirability Functions for Multiparameter Optimization
text: ’ve also developed analogs select_best() show_best() can used jointly optimize multiple metrics directly object produced tune finetune packages. can load results tune::tune_grid() pre-made binary file: demonstrate, ’ve fitted neural network several tuning parameters, including one class_weights. parameter makes model cost-sensitive; weight 2.0 used, minority class training set 2-fold greater impact estimation process. example data set, increasing class weight decreases specificity increases sensitivity (different rates). However, optimize sensitivity, likely get worst specificity value.  Also, want make sure model well calibrated also want minimize Brier score. , can use different verbs: maximize(), minimize(), target(), constrain() metrics tuning parameters. example:
code: library(tune) library(ggplot2)  # Load the results from a cost-sensitive neural network: load(system.file("example-data", "imbalance_example.rda", package = "desirability2"))  tuning_params <- .get_tune_parameter_names(imbalance_example) tuning_params #> [1] "hidden_units"  "penalty"       "activation"    "learn_rate"    #> [5] "stop_iter"     "class_weights"  metrics <- .get_tune_metric_names(imbalance_example) metrics #> [1] "kap"         "brier_class" "roc_auc"     "pr_auc"      "sensitivity" #> [6] "specificity" "mn_log_loss" "mcc" nn_mtr <- collect_metrics(imbalance_example, type = "wide") nn_mtr |>    ggplot(aes(1 - specificity, sensitivity, col = class_weights)) +    geom_point() +    coord_obs_pred() +   theme_bw() +   theme(legend.position = "top") select_best(imbalance_example, metric = "sensitivity") #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   hidden_units penalty activation learn_rate stop_iter class_weights .config     #>          <int>   <dbl> <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl> <chr>       #> 1            5   0.391 tanh          0.00118      5.59          8.76 Preprocess…  select_best(imbalance_example, metric = "specificity") #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   hidden_units penalty activation learn_rate stop_iter class_weights .config     #>          <int>   <dbl> <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl> <chr>       #> 1           24 0.00910 relu           0.0164      1.92             1 Preprocess…  select_best(imbalance_example, metric = "brier_class") #> # Put a little extra importance on the Brier scpre     minimize(brier_class, scale = 2),     maximize(sensitivity),     constrain(specificity, low = 0.75, high = 1)   )  # The resulting desirability functions and their overall mean top_five |>    select(starts_with(".d_")) #> # exp(-10 * abs(v_x - .5))  dat |>   mutate(v = d_custom(x, v_x, v_d)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = x, y = v)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line(alpha = .5) +   lims(x = 0:1, y = 0:1) +   coord_fixed() +   ylab("Desirability")   # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # Qualitative data  set.seed(3) groups <- sort(runif(10)) names(groups) <- letters[1:10]  tibble(x = letters[1:7]) |>   mutate(d = d_category(x, groups)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = x, y = d)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity") +   lims(y = 0:1) +   ylab("Desirability")   # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # Apply the same function to many columns at once (dplyr > 1.0)  dat |>   mutate(across(c(everything()), ~ d_min(., .2, .6), .names = "d_{col}")) #> # A tibble: 30 × 4 #>         x      y   d_x   d_y #>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 0.0134 0.0233 1     1     #>  2 0.0618 0.0707 1     1     #>  3 0.126  0.0995 1     1     #>  4 0.177  0.108  1     1     #>  5 0.202  0.186  0.996 1     #>  6 0.206  0.245  0.985 0.888 #>  7 0.212  0.316  0.970 0.709 #>  8 0.266  0.407  0.836 0.483 #>  9 0.267  0.411  0.832 0.472 #> 10 0.340  0.438  0.649 0.405 #> # ℹ 20 more rows  # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # Using current data  set.seed(9015) tibble(z = c(0, sort(runif(20)), 1)) |>   mutate(     user_specified = d_max(z, 0.1, 0.75),     data_driven   = d_max(z, use_data = TRUE)   ) |>   ggplot(aes(x = z)) +   geom_point(aes(y = user_specified)) +   geom_line(aes(y = user_specified), alpha = .5) +   geom_point(aes(y = data_driven), col = "blue") +   geom_line(aes(y = data_driven), col = "blue", alpha = .5) +   lims(x = 0:1, y = 0:1) +   coord_fixed() +   ylab("Desirability")
